tossups.question: Three-time Nobel Prize nominee Ida Noddack made several correct criticisms of one of this scientist’s major papers. This scientist coined a parameter called age to describe the distance a neutron migrates before becoming thermal. An interaction named for this physicist between an electron and an atomic nucleus is one of the two main contributors to hyperfine coupling. A group of “boys” led by this scientist that discovered slow neutrons included (*) antiproton discoverer Emilio Segrè. The first suggestion of the weak force was proposed in this scientist’s “tentative” model of beta decay. This man names a particle accelerator lab in Batavia, Illinois. For 10 points, name this Italian-American creator of Chicago Pile-1, which was the first nuclear reactor.
tossups.answer: Enrico Fermi
tossups.answer_formatted: Enrico Fermi

tossups.question: A turret and cross atop the arched roof of a building by this architect may represent St. George’s lance piercing a dragon’s back. The twisting wrought-iron balconies and rough-hewn façade of another house by this architect earned it the nickname “the stone quarry.” A mosaic salamander guards the entrance to a (*) park designed by this man. The four Evangelists and Jesus Christ are represented by five of the eighteen spires designed by this man for a church in his hometown. That basilica by this man will be the tallest church in the world when it is completed. For 10 points, name this Catalan Modernisme architect who designed the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona.
tossups.answer: Antoni Gaudí (“gow-DEE”)
tossups.answer_formatted: Antoni Gaudí

tossups.question: Elma boasts of having memorized a passage spoken in this location in William Inge’s play Bus Stop. Lyman subsequently breaks down after reciting the line “My name, dear saint, is… is hateful to myself” from that scene in this place. While at this specific location, one character declares, “My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words of that tongue’s utterance.” That same character in this place wonders how another (*) “camest thou hither” since “the orchard walls are high and hard to climb” and delivers a soliloquy where she states, “That which we call a rose / by any other name would smell as sweet.” For 10 points, Juliet asks “O Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?” while standing at what platform off the side of her room?
tossups.answer: the balcony from Romeo and Juliet [accept any description of the Capulet orchard or garden or the Capulet castle or palace; prompt on Verona]
tossups.answer_formatted: the balcony from Romeo and Juliet [accept any description of the Capulet orchard or gardenaccept the Capulet castle or palace; prompt on Verona]
acceptable: the balcony from Romeo and Juliet
any description of the Capulet orchard

tossups.question: This ruler, who started work on the Epang (“UH-pong”) Palace, survived a metal cone being thrown at him by a big-muscled assassin. This ruler standardized his country’s currency with a copper coin that has a square hole in the center, called the Ban Liang. This man once dispatched an army to aid magicians in searching for the elixir of immortality. His unexcavated pyramid-shaped burial mound at Mount Li contains a large wooden structure within it. This emperor forced aristocrats to relocate to (*) Xianyang (“sh’yen-YONG”) and, on the advice of Li Si (“lee suh”), burned all books on non-practical subjects. In 1974, farmers discovered a pit containing over 6,000 figures buried with this emperor. For 10 points, name this founder of the Qin Dynasty who was buried with a terracotta army.
tossups.answer: Qin Shi Huang [or Shi Huangdi; or Shih-huang-ti; or Ying Zheng; or Zhao Zheng; or Zheng, the King of Qin; or Zhao Zheng; prompt on First Emperor Qin]
tossups.answer_formatted: Qin Shi Huang [or Shi Huangdi; or Shih-huang-ti; or Ying Zheng; or Zhao Zheng; or Zheng, the King of Qin; or Zhao Zheng; prompt on First Emperor Qin]

tossups.question: The first American woman to own one of these businesses, Agnes Thatcher Lake, married “Wild” Bill Hickok in 1876. The first British example of one of these businesses, Astley’s Amphitheatre, employed future explorer of Egypt Giovanni Battista Belzoni and began life as a riding school. A “new” business of this type put on the Zarkana show and an adaptation of the Beatles album Love. One of these businesses was co-named for the man who popularized the phrase “there’s a (*) sucker born every minute” and closed in 2017. Special trains were used by “traveling” businesses of this type to pack up big top tents, often with the help of elephants. For 10 points, name this type of business once operated by the Ringling Brothers.
tossups.answer: circus [or traveling circus; anti-prompt on sideshow or freak show by asking “can you be less specific?”] (P. T. Barnum popularized the phrase; Zarkana and Love were by Cirque du Soleil.)
tossups.answer_formatted: circus [or traveling circus; anti-prompt on sideshow or freak show by asking “can you be less specific?”]
tossups.metadata: P. T. Barnum popularized the phrase; Zarkana and Love were by Cirque du Soleil.

tossups.question: The speaker of a poem witnesses people perform this action with “what belongs to him or her and to none else” while “the day” does it with “what belongs to the day.” In a response to that poem, a man who does this action “too” is “the darker brother” that “they send to eat in the kitchen / When company comes.” A poem titled for this action claims “the universe is a procession with measured and perfect motion” and that “the (*) armies of those I love engirth me.” The seventh section of that poem titled for this action is set at a slave auction, while the ninth lists parts of the human anatomy before declaring “I say now these are the soul.” For 10 points, a Walt Whitman poem is titled for performing what action regarding “the body electric?”
tossups.answer: singing [prompt on synonyms such as caroling; accept “I Hear America Singing”; accept “I, Too Sing America”; accept “I Sing the Body Electric”]
tossups.answer_formatted: singing [prompt on synonyms such as caroling; accept “I Hear America Singing”; accept “I, Too Sing America”; accept “I Sing the Body Electric”]

tossups.question: It’s not “water,” but in an argument against functionalism, Ned Block envisioned a “Twin Earth” scenario in which the language describing this phenomenon is changed. The “knowledge argument” for epiphenomenalism (“epi-phenomenal-ism”), devised by Frank Jackson, proposes that a super-scientist named Mary will learn something upon first experiencing one of these phenomena. The fact that a thirty-year-old man can imagine a form of this phenomenon that he has not experienced seems to contradict the (*) copy principle in An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding. In a thought experiment by Locke, a man functions normally despite seeing an “inverted spectrum” of these visual phenomena. For 10 points, name these qualitative phenomena exemplified by David Hume’s “missing shade of blue.”
tossups.answer: colors [accept shades; prompt on vision or sight]
tossups.answer_formatted: colors [accept shades; prompt on vision or sight]

tossups.question: Six copies of a work by this artist were created by Yves Chaudron (“eev sho-DRON”) according to Karl Decker. Bernardo Bembo may have commissioned a portrait by this artist whose obverse contains the phrase “virtutem forma decorat.” Two portraits by this artist are titled for a type of headband called a ferronnière (“fair-un-YAIR”). A portrait by this man, the only one on permanent display in the Americas, puts its subject in front of a juniper bush, a pun on the sitter’s name (*) Ginevra. Another portrait by him depicts Cecilia Gallerani and is usually called Lady with an Ermine. In his best-known portrait, this artist blended the paints around the mouth and eyes of a member of the Gherardini (“gay-rar-DEE-nee”) family using the sfumato technique. For 10 points, name this artist of the Mona Lisa.
tossups.answer: Leonardo da Vinci [or Leonardo da Vinci]
tossups.answer_formatted: Leonardo da Vinci [or Leonardo da Vinci]

tossups.question: The HDFS file system was developed for this technique and adopted by Apache Spark. The MapReduce model describes algorithms using this technique and remains the idiomatic way to refer to components of Hadoop programs. Problems like raytracing are “embarrassingly” suited to this technique because they minimize resources spent on communication. Semaphores and other locks can maintain strict consistency in this technique, but it is typically eventually consistent because changes take (*) time to propagate. Systems using this technique are more resilient due to their use of clusters, which may have only part of the data. For 10 points, name this technique that divides computational tasks into smaller segments that are performed simultaneously.
tossups.answer: parallel computing [or parallelism; or parallelization; accept distributed computing or distributed files; accept concurrency or concurrent computing; accept cluster or clustered computing before mentioned, but prompt afterward; prompt on async or asynchronous computing; prompt on working with big data by asking “what technique does that rely on?”; do not accept or prompt on “decentralized computing”]
tossups.answer_formatted: parallel computing [or parallelism; or parallelization; accept distributed computing or distributed files; accept concurrency or concurrent computing; accept clusteraccept clustered computing before mentioned, but prompt afterward; prompt on async or asynchronous computing; prompt on working with big data by asking “what technique does that rely on?”; do not accept or prompt on "“decentralized computing”"]
promptable: working with big data by asking “what technique does that rely on?”

tossups.question: In the border region between these two countries, bandits known as reivers (“REE-vurs”) long roamed the “Debatable Land.” An agreement between these two countries was passed when the independent Squadrone Volante (“squa-DRO-nay vo-LAHN-tay”) joined with the Court Party. The churches of these two countries were unified by the Solemn League and Covenant. A later agreement between these two countries was signed after the collapse of the (*) Darien Scheme in modern-day Panama. Forces from one of these countries suppressed the wearing of tartan dress in the other country after the Jacobite rebellions. These two countries were united via the 1707 Acts of Union during the reign of Queen Anne. For 10 points, name these largest two countries on the island of Great Britain.
tossups.answer: England AND Scotland [accept in either order]
tossups.answer_formatted: England AND Scotland [accept in either order]

tossups.question: A sculpture of a girl in a blue dress with the head of one of these creatures is a popular selfie spot in Buffalo, New York. A so-called “alley” named for these creatures attracts tourists to South Africa’s Geyser Rock. The government of New South Wales uses drum lines to cull the population of these creatures, whose fermented meat constitutes a pungent Icelandic dish called (*) hákarl. A Peter Benchley novel based on a series of incidents involving these creatures in New Jersey in 1916 was turned into one of the first movie blockbusters. Deep-water varieties of these species tend to have large, fatty livers. For 10 points, name these creatures whose “great white” variety occasionally attack humans.
tossups.answer: sharks [or Selachimorpha; or Selachii; accept sharkgirl or Shark Island; accept more specific shark varieties like great white shark; prompt on fish] (The Benchley novel was Jaws.)
tossups.answer_formatted: sharks [or Selachimorpha; or Selachii; accept sharkgirl or Shark Island; accept more specific shark varieties like great white shark; prompt on fish]
acceptable: more specific shark varieties like great white shark

tossups.question: This story takes place during a time when “experiments with the action of magnetism had occupied public attention,” causing great interest in dancing chairs. Its protagonist is denied a request to take out a newspaper advertisement because a previous advertisement about a poodle turned out to be a libelous allegory. This story’s title character is spotted boarding a stagecoach for Riga by a policeman who mistook him for a gentleman. Its title character was earlier found in a (*) loaf of bread by the barber Ivan Yakovlevich (“YAH-kove-lay-vitch”). This story’s protagonist, Kovalyov, compares part of himself to being as flat as “a newly fried pancake.” For 10 points, name this Nikolai Gogol story where the title body part goes missing from the protagonist’s face.
tossups.answer: “The Nose” [or “Nos”]
tossups.answer_formatted: “The Nose” [or “Nos”]

tossups.question: An 1852 federal law named for these things transferred regulation of them to the Treasury Department and required the use of the Bourdon safety tube. A former Governor of New Jersey sued a business partner for violating a monopoly on the use of these things in a case involving a young Cornelius Vanderbilt. “Mud clerks” worked on these things. One of the first of these things was built for Robert R. Livingston and was named for New Orleans. Men operating these things such as Horace E. Bixby had the difficult job of avoiding (*) tree snags. One of these things was nicknamed Fulton’s Folly prior to its successful voyage to Albany. Samuel Clemens got his pen name from a term used on, for 10 points, what vehicles that could sail up the Mississippi?
tossups.answer: steamboats [accept paddle steamers; prompt on river boats or boats or ships or other types of boats]
tossups.answer_formatted: steamboats [accept paddle steamers; prompt on river boats or boats or ships or other types of boats]

tossups.question: In an incident involving this woman, which was depicted in an unfinished epic by Claudian, the swineherd Eubuleus (“yoo-BULL-ee-us”) lost his pigs. In the Orphic religion, this woman and Zeus are the parents of Zagreus, a Dionysus analogue gobbled up by the Titans. In the Metamorphoses, this woman turns Ascalaphus (“ass-CAL-uh-fuss”) into an owl by splashing him with water. Theseus’s friend (*) Pirithous is glued to a stone bench forever for trying to abduct this woman. This woman raises Adonis from infancy and feuds with Aphrodite over him. Because this woman ate some pomegranate seeds, she is obliged to spend a third of each year underground. For 10 points, name this daughter of Demeter who becomes queen of the underworld after being abducted by Hades.
tossups.answer: Persephone [or Proserpina; or Proserpine; or Kore]
tossups.answer_formatted: Persephone [or Proserpina; or Proserpine; or Kore]

tossups.question: Channels for transporting this substance are damaged in PSC, which subsequently may cause steatorrhea (“stee-AT-oh-REE-uh”). Taurine and glycine conjugate many of the components of this substance. ALP and GGT are two enzymes that are elevated when the flow of this substance is obstructed. Release of the hormone CCK induces the sphincter of Oddi to relax to release this substance through the (*) cystic duct. The majority of this substance’s mass is composed of acids derived from the oxidation of cholesterol. Blockage of this substance leads to jaundice due to a buildup of bilirubin. This substance emulsifies lipids in the duodenum. For 10 points, name this yellow-green fluid produced in the liver and stored in the gallbladder.
tossups.answer: bile [or bile acids; or bile salts; accept gall before “gallbladder” is mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: bile [or bile acids; or bile salts; accept gall before “gallbladder” is mentioned]

tossups.question: A religious text compiled by this thinker was recovered by Cyrus Adler after he found other books with passages snipped out of them. This thinker commemorated Ramadan by hosting an iftar dinner in honor of the Tunisian emissary Sidi Soliman Mellimelli. Denise Spellberg’s book on this thinker’s relationship to Islam describes his purchase of a Qur’an that was later used by (*) Keith Ellison. This thinker’s namesake “Bible,” made by literally cutting and pasting sections of the New Testament, removed all references to the supernatural. For 10 points, name this heterodox religious thinker and political leader who insisted that “Men… are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable Rights” in the Declaration of Independence.
tossups.answer: Thomas Jefferson
tossups.answer_formatted: Thomas Jefferson

tossups.question: This author wrote “In my barren land you are the final rose” in a poem that addresses “Ah you who are silent!” Another poem by this writer states “There were grief and the ruins, and you were the miracle.” The 1969 Penguin translation of this author’s “Every Day You Play” by W. S. Merwin concludes “I want to do with you what spring does with the cherry trees.” This poet of “White Bee” wrote of “white (*) hills, white thighs” in “Body of a Woman,” which begins a collection by this poet whose final poem opens, “The memory of you emerges from the night around me.” That work by this poet contains the refrains “It is the hour of departure” and “In you everything sank!” For 10 points, name this Chilean poet of Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair.
tossups.answer: Pablo Neruda [or Ricardo Eliécer Neftalí Reyes Basoalto]
tossups.answer_formatted: Pablo Neruda [or Ricardo Eliécer Neftalí Reyes Basoalto]

tossups.question: Abu Zayd al-Balkhi named a medieval school for producing these objects in Baghdad. In the 19th century, a celebrated object of this kind was produced by the working-class William “Strata” Smith. Jerry Brotton, who wrote a “History of the World” based on 12 of these objects, highlights the cultural exchange in Muhammad al-Idrisi’s example, the Tabula Rogeriana. One of these objects produced in Nuremberg posits the existence of (*) four-eyed men and centaurs. The inaccurate Cosmographia of Claudius Ptolemy inspired medieval makers of these things like Martin Waldseemüller. One of these objects notable for its size distortions was made in 1569 by Gerardus Mercator. For 10 points, cartographers produce what objects that are useful in navigation?
tossups.answer: maps [or atlases; or world map; or globes; accept geological map; prompt on geographical survey; prompt on a projection; prompt on charts]
tossups.answer_formatted: maps [or atlases; or world map; or globes; accept geological map; prompt on geographical survey; prompt on a projection; prompt on charts]

tossups.question: Bill Keith invented namesake devices that let players of this instrument quickly switch from G to D tuning, and pioneered the “melodic” style of playing it. Players of this instrument frequently use the right hand to create repeated patterns of eighth-note arpeggios known as “rolls.” Traditional players of this instrument use the (*) claw-hammer technique to play the “bum-ditty” pattern. This instrument rose in popularity thanks to the song “Foggy Mountain Breakdown,” which was written and recorded by Earl Scruggs. Béla Fleck plays this instrument, which typically has either four or five strings and a circular membrane, and was brought to America by African slaves. For 10 points, name this string instrument commonly used in bluegrass music.
tossups.answer: banjo
tossups.answer_formatted: banjo

tossups.question: Two molecules that both have this many carbons are produced at the start of one pathway’s non-oxidative phase and act as substrates for transketolase. IPP (“I-P-P”) and DMAPP both have this many carbons and are the building blocks of terpenes, which all have multiples of this many carbons. Alpha-ketoglutarate has this many carbons and is formed through the oxidative decarboxylation of the tricarboxylic acid isocitrate. The carboxylation of a molecule with this many carbons by (*) RuBisCO creates an intermediate that immediately splits into two molecules of G3P. Sugars with this many carbons are joined by phosphate groups in the backbone of nucleic acids. For 10 points, how many carbons are in ribose and other outputs of the pentose phosphate pathway?
tossups.answer: five [prompt on the pentose phosphate pathway before mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: five [prompt on the pentose phosphate pathway before mentioned]

tossups.question: Sephardic Jews celebrate some of these events with a zeved (“ZEH-ved”) ceremony, which includes the recitation of two verses addressing “my dove” from the Song of Songs. An Ashkenazi custom during these events is to hang up the text of Psalm 121. Some of these events are followed 31 days later by a pidyon (“peed-YOHN”), a “redemption” paid in coins. Some of these events are followed eight days later by a ceremony at which a chair is reserved for the prophet (*) Elijah. That ceremony for boys, which involves the participation of a sandak (“SAHN-duck”) and mohel (“MOY-ull”), is called a brit milah (“breet mee-LAH”) and centers on a boy’s circumcision following one of these events. For 10 points, name this fulfillment of the Bible’s first command, “Be fruitful and multiply.”
tossups.answer: childbirth [accept equivalents like having a baby or having a child; accept naming or equivalents before “hang” is read] (The zeved ha-bat ceremony celebrates the birth of a daughter.)
tossups.answer_formatted: childbirth [accept equivalents like having a baby or having a child; accept namingaccept equivalents before “hang” is read]
tossups.metadata: The zeved ha-bat ceremony celebrates the birth of a daughter.

bonuses.leadin: This economist used the example of grass being destroyed by neighboring rabbits to show the need for a certain tax. For 10 points each:
answers: Arthur Pigou [or Arthur Cecil Pigou; accept Pigouvian tax]
parts: Name this economist whose namesake taxes can provide a double dividend by discouraging socially damaging behavior and using the tax proceeds to solve other social problems.
Pigovian taxes can correct market failures from the negative form of these things, the difference between the private and social cost of an action.

Pigou’s Real Balance effect hypothesizes that deflation causes demand, output and employment all to rise. This economist studied deflation during the Great Depression and preceded Janet Yellen as Fed Chair.

bonuses.leadin: In 1938, over 100 people dressed as this man marched in protest of FDR’s plan to reform the presidency. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man whose best-known feat was accomplished in conjunction with William Dawes, helping Samuel Adams and John Hancock avoid capture.
Paul Revere was intercepted by British forces before he could get to this town. Along with Lexington, this town names a battle in which the “shot heard round the world” started the Revolutionary War.
After the war, Revere founded the first American rolling mill for this good. Three Gilded Age “Kings” who fought for control of this good included Marcus Daly, the founder of Anaconda Mining Company.

bonuses.leadin: Grazing angles allow this value for a thin layer to be much greater than the thickness. For 10 points each:
answers: optical path length [accept optical path length difference, OPLD, or optical distance; prompt on geometric distance or length]

attenuated total internal reflection [or TIR; accept attenuated total reflection, attenuated total reflectance, or ATR-FTIR spectroscopy; accept frustrated total internal reflection; prompt on reflection]
parts: Name this quantity changed in a Michelson interferometer to produce a range of frequencies for Fourier transform IR spectroscopy. This quantity is determined by both geometric parameters and the index of refraction.
FTIR (“F-T-I-R”) spec can use the attenuation of evanescent waves produced by this phenomenon to minimize the extinction produced by path length inside a sample.
One of these objects is moved in order to change the path length in an interferometer. These objects rely on conventional reflection to reverse the direction of incoming light.
answers_formatted: optical path length [accept optical path length difference, OPLD, or optical distance; prompt on geometric distance or length]

attenuated total internal reflection [or TIR; accept attenuated total reflection, attenuated total reflectance, or ATR-FTIR spectroscopy; accept frustrated total internal reflection; prompt on reflection]
acceptable: attenuated total reflection, attenuated total reflectance,

bonuses.leadin: It’s not a church, but Mary Baker Eddy founded one of these institutions with the intention “To injure no man, but to bless all mankind.” For 10 points each:
answers: newspapers [accept news media or news industry; accept periodicals; prompt on publishing or publishers; prompt on media; prompt on printing or printers]
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints [accept LDS Church; accept Mormon Church or Mormons]
parts: Name these institutions that include The Christian Science Monitor. While working at The Monitor, Kay Fanning became the first female editor of a national one of these institutions.
In a 2019 editorial, this evangelical magazine founded by Billy Graham called for Donald Trump’s impeachment, citing its 1998 editorial on Clinton’s impeachment.
This church publishes the Deseret (“dez-uh-RET”) News, which takes its name from a historical unrecognized U.S. state.
answers_formatted: newspapers [accept news media or news industry; accept periodicals; prompt on publishing or publishers; prompt on media; prompt on printing or printers]
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints [accept LDS Church; accept Mormon Church or Mormons]
acceptable: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints

bonuses.leadin: This choreographer’s vigorous smoking habit is satirized when his stand-in smokes in the shower in a scene from All That Jazz. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this Tony-winning dance choreographer of The Pajama Game and Chicago. He emphasized the use of “jazz hands” for his dancers.
Fosse choreographed this sports musical, whose song “Whatever Lola Wants” was inspired by a dancer and mistress of Bavaria’s King Ludwig I.

Fosse included multiple dance styles for the 1959 musical Redhead, including this one still widely performed by chorus lines. This once-scandalous French dance features vigorous high-kicks and is performed in Jacques Offenbach’s Orpheus in the Underworld.

bonuses.leadin: This character gives his nephew’s hand in marriage to a “clever slave” who performs a sword dance in order to kill a man using the alias Khwaja Hasan. For 10 points each:
answers: Arabian Nights’ Entertainment [or One Thousand and One Nights; or Kitab alf Layla wa Layla]
parts: Name this brother of Kassim who uses the magic words “Open Sesame” in one story.
Scheherazade tells the story of Ali Baba to her husband Shahriyar to delay her execution in this collection of folktales.
In the tale of Ali Baba, this slave protects her master by pouring boiling oil on thirty-seven men hiding in leather jars.
answers_formatted: Arabian Nights’ Entertainment [or One Thousand and One Nights; or Kitab alf Layla wa Layla]

bonuses.leadin: This practice began in the 1850s after a child named Nongqawuse ("nong-KA-woo-say") claimed to have met her ancestors. For 10 points each:
answers: Xhosa (“ko-sa”) cattle killing movement [accept equivalents; prompt on Chiefs Plot or Grey’s Plot]
South Africa [or Republic of South Africa]
Shaka Zulu [or Tshaka; or Chaka; or Shaka kaSenzangakhona]
parts: Name this practice that was undertaken by one ethnic group to drive the British out and end “lung sickness.” Instead, this practice resulted in a large famine in the British Kaffraria.
The Xhosa (“ko-sa”) undertook the cattle killing movement in this modern-day country. It was later led by Nelson Mandela.
After the death of his mother, Nandi, this man ordered thousands of cows to be slaughtered and banned milk drinking. This chieftain developed the successful “bull horn” formation.

bonuses.leadin: This character greatly fears that he has broken a crystal bowl given to him by Victor, the son of one of his ex-lovers, after accidentally dropping a nutcracker into it. For 10 points each:
answers: Vladimir Nabokov [or Vladimir Vladimirovich Nabokov; or Vladimir Sirin]
parts: Name this character whose story is told by Vladimir Vladimirovich. He is ultimately fired from his position in the Russian department at Waindell College by Dr. Hagen.
Pnin is a novel by this Russian-American author of Lolita.

The final chapter of Pnin reveals the narrator to be Vladimir Vladimirovich, a man interested in these creatures, a recurring interest of Nabokov’s. In 2016, Yale University Press published Nabokov’s scientific drawings of these creatures.

bonuses.leadin: This term was coined by the late Carl Woese (“woze”) after he defined one called Archaea. For 10 points each:
answers: rRNA [accept ribosomal RNA; accept “ribonucleic acid” in place of “RNA”; prompt on RNA or ribonucleic acid; do not accept or prompt on “ribosome”]
parts: Name this highest taxonomic rank. The three categories in this rank are Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya.

Woese’s discovery of Archaea used his analysis of the gene coding for the 16S example of this molecule. The 16S and 23S examples of these molecules form the 30S and 50S subunits of a larger structure.
In Archaea, this phospholipid-based structure contains ether-linked lipids instead of ester-linked ones, and sometimes contains a monolayer in place of a lipid bilayer.
answers_formatted: rRNA [accept ribosomal RNA; accept “ribonucleic acid” in place of “RNA”; prompt on RNA or ribonucleic acid; do not accept or prompt on "“ribosome”"]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the growing trend for super-wealthy state governors:
parts: Bill Haslam, the former governor of this state, was once the U.S.’s wealthiest elected official. Bill Lee now governs this state, the only one with a free community college program.
Jim Justice, the governor of this state, is also its wealthiest private citizen. Justice made his fortune in coal, which was once the key industry of this Appalachian state south of Pennsylvania.
This governor’s fortune was made through the Plumpjack Winery. This governor’s violations of his own COVID rules to attend a fundraiser at the French Laundry have endangered his political career.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the quest for women’s suffrage around the world.
answers: Sierra Leone [or Republic of Sierra Leone; or Salone]
China [or People's Republic of China] (The quote is from Mao.)
parts: Women householders in this British colony had the right to vote since 1792, although those rights were restricted over time. This West African colony received over 50,000 “recaptives” between 1807 and 1864.
Unlike a larger neighbor, indigenous Maori women were not excluded from this country’s pioneering 1893 women’s suffrage bill.

Women’s suffrage advocates in this country broke the windows of its Parliament in 1912 but weren’t granted the technical right to vote until 1947. Women in this country were later said to “hold up half the sky.”

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s second and third piano concerti in A minor and B minor, respectively, heavily influenced Frédéric Chopin’s two piano concerti. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this non-Haydn composer, who wrote an E major trumpet concerto for Anton Weidinger.
Hummel published a “Complete Theoretical and Practical Course of Instruction on the Art of Playing” this instrument. Today, this instrument has 88 black and white keys.

Hummel taught pianist Louise Farrenc, who only began receiving equal pay as a composer after having one of her pieces premiered by Joseph Joachim (“YO-zef YO-ah-kim”), a player of this instrument. Modern players of this instrument include Janine Jansen (“ja-NEEN YON-sin”) and Hilary Hahn.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about alcohol in the novels of Charles Dickens.
answers: spontaneous combustion [accept descriptive equivalents like bursting into flames; prompt on burning or combustion]
parts: A crowd laps up wine from a broken cask on the streets of Paris, foreshadowing the French Revolution, in a famous passage of this Dickens novel. It opens with “It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.”
This scheming Dickens villain encourages Mr. Wickfield’s drinking problem in an effort to marry his daughter Agnes and take over his law office.
In a Dickensian attack on alcoholism from Bleak House, a penchant for gin causes the rag and bone man Krook to suffer this unfortunate fate, whose plausibility is addressed in the novel’s preface.
answers_formatted: spontaneous combustion [accept descriptive equivalents like bursting into flames; prompt on burning or combustion]
acceptable: descriptive equivalents like bursting into flames

bonuses.leadin: In the middle of the 19th century, the number of planets ballooned to 23. For 10 points each:
answers: asteroids [accept asteroid belt; accept planetoids or minor planets]
orbital resonance with Neptune [accept resonant trans-Neptunian objects or resonant TNOs; prompt on being inside the Kuiper belt or beyond Neptune by asking “what property does their orbit have?”]
parts: The discovery of Pallas, Juno, and their many small companions forced scientists to create this new category to contain them, returning the number of planets to seven.
In 1846, the French and British agreed to share credit for the prediction and discovery of this eighth planet, which is still considered one today.

In contrast, newcomer Pluto was deprived of planet status by the IAU after the discovery of other trans-Neptunian objects and is now in a category defined by this orbital property. Objects with this property include the plutinos and twotinos.
answers_formatted: orbital resonance with Neptune [accept resonant trans-Neptunian objects or resonant TNOs; prompt on being inside the Kuiper belt or beyond Neptune by asking “what property does their orbit have?”]
promptable: beyond Neptune by asking “what property does their orbit have?”

bonuses.leadin: In Venice, this tradition was largely ended with the Napoleonic invasion, but was revived in the 1970s. For 10 points each:
answers: the plague [or bubonic plague; prompt on black death]
parts: Identify this weeks-long annual celebration where Venetians donned masks such as the bauta, which was later featured in Stanley Kubrick’s Eyes Wide Shut.
Beak-nosed masks were used by Venetian physicians to avoid contracting this disease. Perhaps 200 million people died during a “great” outbreak of this disease in the 14th century.

Another Venetian tradition, the Marriage to the Sea, concluded with the doge consecrating one of these objects. Pope Alexander III gave one of these objects to a Venetian doge for fighting a campaign against Frederick Barbarossa.

bonuses.leadin: Aloysius Bertrand (“ah-loy-zee-OOSE bair-TAWN”) rejected the dominance of alexandrine meter by publishing Gaspard de la Nuit, a collection of poems in this genre. For 10 points each:
answers: spleen [accept The Spleen of Paris or “Spleen and Ideal”]
dice [or die; or dés; accept The Dice Cup or “A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance”]
parts: Give this genre of poetry written in paragraphs rather than lines. It is named for a form of writing contrasted with verse.
Charles Baudelaire declares “Be Drunk!” in a prose poetry collection titled for this melancholic concept. The first section of Baudelaire’s Les Fleurs du Mal pits this concept against the Ideal.

Max Jacob wrote a collection of Cubist prose poems titled for a “cup” of these objects. Jacob was inspired by a Stéphane Mallarmé poem in free verse about these objects that experiments with typography.
answers_formatted: spleen [accept The Spleen of Paris or “Spleen and Ideal”]
dice [or die; or dés; accept The Dice Cup or “A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance”]
acceptable: “A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance”

bonuses.leadin: In 1999, the Detroit Institute of Arts cancelled a show that would have included a Jef Bourgeau installation titled for this object that traced the history of art controversies. For 10 points each:
answers: Vincent Van Gogh’s ear [prompt on ear by asking “whose ear?”]
Paul Gauguin [or Eugène Henri Paul Gauguin]
parts: Identify this object that is missing from a self-portrait in which the artist wears a green jacket and smokes a pipe.
Van Gogh may have severed his ear due to a conflict with this fellow artist in Arles (“arl”). This post-Impressionist painter of The Yellow Christ later moved to Tahiti.

Surrealist Meret (“MEH-ret”) Oppenheim sculpted this artist’s ear, replacing the earlobe with a fist. Henri Cartier-Bresson photographed this artist maneuvering a work among his numerous spindly-looking sculptures.
answers_formatted: Vincent Van Gogh’s ear [prompt on ear by asking “whose ear?”]

bonuses.leadin: Martin Heidegger argued that this phrase only applied to Christians and declared that this phrase means that “the suprasensory world is without effective power.” For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this three-word phrase that first appeared spoken by the “madman” in Section 125 of The Gay Science.
The Gay Science was written by this German philosopher who also wrote Beyond Good and Evil.

In The Gay Science, Nietzsche uses this two-word Latin phrase to denote his “formula for greatness in a human being.” Nietzsche defines this attitude as "not merely bearing what is necessary… but loving it."

bonuses.leadin: In the Lokasenna, this woman foretells the binding of Loki. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this giantess, a daughter of Thiazzi who married the sea god Niord.

The prose afterword to the Lokasenna says that it was Skadi who placed one of these animals above the bound Loki. Another of these animals, Jörmungandr (“YOR-mun-gahn-dur”), is so long that it encircles the world and bites its own tail.

Skadi was given the right to choose a husband from among the gods, but was only allowed to look at these body parts of theirs before choosing. As a result, Skadi ended up choosing Niord rather than Baldr.

bonuses.leadin: Akira Yoshino helped make this technology practical with his research into petroleum coke, a byproduct from making fossil fuels. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this technology co-developed by Yoshino, Stanley Whittingham, and John Goodenough, all three of whom received the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
Yoshino used the petroleum coke to hold lithium ions in this part of the battery, through which the current flows into an electrical device, unlike the cathode.
Lithium ions may also be intercalated between sheets of this material consisting of sheets of hexagonally arranged carbon atoms.

bonuses.leadin: Since the 7th century, this religious shrine has been reconstructed every 20 years as part of a ritual called the shikinen sengū (“shkee-nen sen-goo”). For 10 points each:
answers: rice [prompt on food or crops or grain or harvest]
parts: Identify this shrine that houses the Sacred Mirror behind four wooden barriers. Princess Ōku is held to be the first Saiō (“sigh-oh”), a royal high priestess, to serve at this shrine.
The Ise Shrine is dedicated to Amaterasu, a kami from this Japanese religion.

The Ise Shrine is the site of the annual Kannamesai (“kahn-nah-meh-sigh”) Festival, during which the emperor personally offers some of this stuff to Amaterasu. The kami Inari is named after a “load” of this stuff, and patronizes this stuff’s production.
